title: 2014 Chevrolet COPO Camaro 427 #4
description: This 2014 Chevrolet COPO Camaro is #4 of 69 examples produced for the model year for competition in NHRA’s Stock Eliminator and Super Stock categories, and it was reportedly campaigned under prior ownership. The car is finished in Summit White over a race-prepped interior, and its 427ci V8 sends power to the rear wheels through an ATI Racing Products three-speed TH400 automatic transmission and a Strange Engineering differential. Equipment includes staggered-width Weld wheels, Strange Engineering brake and suspension components, a Hurst Quarter Stick shifter, a roll cage, window nets, wheelie bars, COPO graphics, AutoMeter auxiliary gauges, and dash-mounted switchgear. This COPO Camaro is now offered by the selling dealer for off-road use only with historical photographs, accessories, and a bill of sale.
author: bringatrailer
excerpt: Bid for the chance to own a 2014 Chevrolet COPO Camaro 427 #4 at auction with Bring a Trailer, the home of the best vintage and classic cars online. Lot #203,340.
text: This 2014 Chevrolet COPO Camaro is #4 of 69 examples produced for the model year for competition in NHRA’s Stock Eliminator and Super Stock categories, and it was reportedly campaigned under prior ownership. The car is finished in Summit White over a race-prepped interior, and its 427ci V8 sends power to the rear wheels through an ATI Racing Products three-speed TH400 automatic transmission and a Strange Engineering differential. Equipment includes staggered-width Weld wheels, Strange Engineering brake and suspension components, a Hurst Quarter Stick shifter, a roll cage, window nets, wheelie bars, COPO graphics, AutoMeter auxiliary gauges, and dash-mounted switchgear. This COPO Camaro is now offered by the selling dealer for off-road use only with historical photographs, accessories, and a bill of sale. The car is said to have been campaigned across several events under prior ownership, reportedly achieving a best quarter-mile time of 9.31 seconds at 146 miles per hour. Each COPO Camaro was modified by the factory for racing use and sold without a VIN. This example is finished in Summit White and features blue COPO graphics, wheelie bars, a cowl hood, a rear spoiler, and a rear bumper-mounted fuel shut-off switch. Staggered-width 15″ Weld Racing wheels feature COPO branding and wear Hoosier tires. Braking is provided by Strange Engineering slotted rotors with four-piston calipers, and the suspension system consists of Strange Engineering coilovers up front with a four-bar setup featuring adjustable top links out back. The race-prepped cabin is equipped with a safety cage, window nets, and black cloth bucket seats with pass-throughs for racing harnesses. Additional equipment includes netting installed on the driver’s side, switchgear mounted in the dash in lieu of a stereo, and a Hurst Quarter Stick shifter. The cluster houses a speedometer and a tachometer, while supplementary AutoMeter instrumentation features gold bowtie logos and consists of an auxiliary 10k-rpm tachometer mounted on the A-pillar as well as readouts for oil pressure, water temperature, fuel pressure, and transmission fluid temperature housed in the center of the dashboard. COPO Camaros were not delivered with odometers, and chassis mileage is unknown. The 427ci V8 features an LS7 aluminum engine block, wet-sump lubrication, and CNC-fabricated aluminum heads. Additional details include Holley and Aeromotive fueling components, American Racing headers, dual batteries, and a Whippple aluminum throttle body. The powerplant was rated by the factory at 430 horsepower. Power is sent to the rear wheels via an ATI Racing Products three-speed TH400 automatic transmission and a Strange Engineering 9″ rear end with 4.57:1 gears, an aluminum center section, and a lightweight steel spool. The COPO documentation shows the build specifications and serial number. The car lacks an identification number, is not legal for road use, and carries no title or registration. It is being sold on a bill of sale. You are not connected to real-time updates. Attempting to connect. Your real-time updates could not be connected. html:
This 2014 Chevrolet COPO Camaro is #4 of 69 examples produced for the model year for competition in NHRA’s Stock Eliminator and Super Stock categories, and it was reportedly campaigned under prior ownership. The car is finished in Summit White over a race-prepped interior, and its 427ci V8 sends power to the rear wheels through an ATI Racing Products three-speed TH400 automatic transmission and a Strange Engineering differential. Equipment includes staggered-width Weld wheels, Strange Engineering brake and suspension components, a Hurst Quarter Stick shifter, a roll cage, window nets, wheelie bars, COPO graphics, AutoMeter auxiliary gauges, and dash-mounted switchgear. This COPO Camaro is now offered by the selling dealer for off-road use only with historical photographs, accessories, and a bill of sale.

The car is said to have been campaigned across several events under prior ownership, reportedly achieving a best quarter-mile time of 9.31 seconds at 146 miles per hour.

Each COPO Camaro was modified by the factory for racing use and sold without a VIN. This example is finished in Summit White and features blue COPO graphics, wheelie bars, a cowl hood, a rear spoiler, and a rear bumper-mounted fuel shut-off switch.

Staggered-width 15″ Weld Racing wheels feature COPO branding and wear Hoosier tires. Braking is provided by Strange Engineering slotted rotors with four-piston calipers, and the suspension system consists of Strange Engineering coilovers up front with a four-bar setup featuring adjustable top links out back.

The race-prepped cabin is equipped with a safety cage, window nets, and black cloth bucket seats with pass-throughs for racing harnesses. Additional equipment includes netting installed on the driver’s side, switchgear mounted in the dash in lieu of a stereo, and a Hurst Quarter Stick shifter.

The cluster houses a speedometer and a tachometer, while supplementary AutoMeter instrumentation features gold bowtie logos and consists of an auxiliary 10k-rpm tachometer mounted on the A-pillar as well as readouts for oil pressure, water temperature, fuel pressure, and transmission fluid temperature housed in the center of the dashboard. COPO Camaros were not delivered with odometers, and chassis mileage is unknown.

The 427ci V8 features an LS7 aluminum engine block, wet-sump lubrication, and CNC-fabricated aluminum heads. Additional details include Holley and Aeromotive fueling components, American Racing headers, dual batteries, and a Whippple aluminum throttle body. The powerplant was rated by the factory at 430 horsepower.

Power is sent to the rear wheels via an ATI Racing Products three-speed TH400 automatic transmission and a Strange Engineering 9″ rear end with 4.57:1 gears, an aluminum center section, and a lightweight steel spool.

The COPO documentation shows the build specifications and serial number.

The car lacks an identification number, is not legal for road use, and carries no title or registration. It is being sold on a bill of sale.
